channel.title: .NET Dependency VS Java Dependency
channel.description:
Which is better? Having a program compiled in CIL ~ .NET Framework or JAVA
Since most windows XP come with netframework2.0 + and no windows come with java I'd vote for .NET

item.title: .NET Dependency VS Java Dependency
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

Moparisthebest:

I’ve had to install many huge .net framework libraries on windows PCs, it’s a pain in the ass. Java runs everywhere, Linux, Windows, and Mac. Java is also a more mature technology than .net. I believe Java is much better and that’s what I use. I don’t believe I’ll ever use .net at all.

Not everyone is such a fan of cross-platform interoperability. And as said before there’s Mono. I use Java regularly, but .NET is infact better. If C++ wasn’t my main language and I had to choose between Java and C#/.NET I’d definately go for .NET. If your software is not a toy program there’s a big chance it will need platform specific functionality, doing it via JNI is just a huge mess.

Read full topic

item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

I Vain I - Java is external to windows, and while some new system come with it pre-installed, it is not built in, and most certainly not all computers come with it.

Also, I know on my XP laptop (which is very old), it didn’t come with .NET, I needed to manually install a new service pack.

item.title: .NET Dependency VS Java Dependency
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

I really wonder what special versions of Windows you guys are running. The java.exe and javaw.exe files in system32 are actually planted by the Java installion, they’re not there by default. It could be that Windows XP comes with Microsoft VM(not sure right now), but it certainly aint true for newer Windows versions as Sun sued MS for that.

The dependencies: .NET is obviously installed on more systems, Vista and 7 have it by default, XP has it from the service packs. If you’re developing applications for Windows and are wondering wether to use .NET or Java then the only sensible choice would be to go for .NET.

Read full topic
